description:
Aspergillus steynii IBT 23096 is a filamentous fungal species that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It is a member of the Aspergillus section Fumigati, which is known for its potential to produce mycotoxins.

Aspergillus steynii IBT 23096 is a heterothallic fungus, meaning it requires two compatible mating types to undergo sexual reproduction. The species is primarily known to reproduce asexually, producing large numbers of small, greenish-gray spores (conidia) on specialized reproductive structures called conidiophores.

Morphologically, the colony of A. steynii IBT 23096 typically appears velvety or powdery, with a greenish-gray to dark green color. Microscopically, the conidiophores are smooth-walled, and the conidia are globose to subglobose in shape.

Ecologically, A. steynii IBT 23096 is commonly found in soil, decaying organic matter, and indoor environments. It is considered an opportunistic pathogen, capable of causing invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised individuals.

Further research on the physiology, secondary metabolite production, and potential toxicological properties of A. steynii IBT 23096 is ongoing to better understand its role in the environment and potential implications for human health.
